Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Surviving the Flood: Vulnerability, Risk Management, and Resilience after a Natural Disaster

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Natural disasters impact all populations but poorer, rural populations are particularly vulnerable. We know from research in large-scale modern societies that wealthier, healthier, and more educated individuals have greater resilience to adverse events. However, in much of United States as well as in the world at large, there remain people living at or near the poverty line. Natural disasters can push people over that line into "poverty traps" from which they may never recover. Therefore, understanding factors that promote resilience in populations with limited schooling, material wealth, and access to good healthcare is critical for developing programs and policies that will protect all Americans from the long-term effects of disasters.

The research will be conducted in lowland Bolivia where there was catastrophic flooding in early 2014. This is a particularly apt research setting because the investigators have done research in this site since 2002. Therefore, they have detailed, individual-level baseline data with which to make comparisons. They also can leverage existing infrastructure and support, which allows a small amount of funding now to produce significant research impact. The researchers will focus on the Tsimane Amerindians who practice a subsistence lifestyle based on horticulture, fishing, and hunting. The 2014 floods destroyed crops and possessions in over sixty Tsimane villages; widespread food insecurity and disease are expected to follow. Due to the extent of the losses, wealth inequality has likely been substantially reduced across households and villages. The investigators will assess whether involvement in the local market economy, schooling, and social connections helped protect families against the losses from the floods and whether these factors will help buffer families during the period of recovery. Investigators will also assess whether wealth inequalities that existed prior to the flood re-emerge one year after the flood. Investigators will visit affected villages, conduct surveys, collect information on health, nutritional status and activities, and assay stress hormones from salivary samples. Findings from this research will provide insight into the factors that promote and perpetuate poverty traps by examining the extent to which social subordination, low human capital and lack of psychological resilience impact recovery efforts and restoration of well-being and economic productivity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We obtained a one-year NSF RAPID grant to study impacts of catastrophic flooding among Tsimane Native American forager-horticulturalists of lowland Bolivia in February 2014. Natural disasters impact all populations, yet rural, indigenous populations who live “off the grid” are particularly vulnerable. We mobilized a fully trained binational research team to visit 25 remote villages, interviewing 655 households (2,327 individuals) within the first three months of the flooding about losses, patterns of sharing, borrowing, and debt. We also assessed physical and emotional health, time discounting, nutritional status of children, and plans for economic recovery. Saliva specimens were collected among 421 household heads and analyzed for four biomarkers related to psychosocial stress, immune function and health status. A follow-up interview was administered to 103 households, or 16% of the households observed within three months of the flood.

Preliminary findings suggest that most households in the Tsimane territory were impacted by the flood. Crop loss was the main complaint, with many households losing a large percentage of multiple staple crops. During the period of peak flooding, many households evacuated their villages, and have subsequently either relocated their homes, or have migrated to another village to live with distant kin. Based on comparisons one year prior to the flood, our biomedical team determined that Tsimane were in worse physical and emotional health following the flood; many lost weight, had greater risk of anemia, and greater risk of infection. Indeed, Tsimane were almost three times more likely to be anemic and more than twice as likely to have elevated white blood cell counts (indicating high immune burden) in the months following the flood. These effects are much stronger than the year-to-year variation we have observed in previous rounds of biomedical data collection in the previous decade. Men and women’s mental health were also affected by the flood. Men who suffered crop losses experienced more trouble sleeping and an inability to get negative thoughts out of their mind. Women instead were more likely to have trouble sleeping, and to experience depressed affect if their children became sick due to flood-related events. To cope with crop losses, more people relied more on extended sharing networks, suggesting that disaster can lead to an expansion of one’s risk pooling network. This finding runs counter to common claims that disaster can increase selfishness and lead to a contraction of sharing networks. 

In addition to documenting the material losses, our dataset enables us to conduct the types of analyses that will be of scientific value to those studying the larger ramifications of natural disasters, including those studying rural poverty, community development and indigenous well-being. We will assess the determinants of psychological and physical health pre- and post-flood, and the ability of existing social networks to adequately buffer losses. Given the heterogeneous and shifting socioeconomic transformation affecting Tsimane villages, we will also test whether greater integration to the market, schooling and social ties to non-Tsimane help or hinder recovery efforts. Coupled with other datasets from previous research by our team, we can also assess the extent to which the flood leveled pre-existing economic inequalities. Our project provides a valuable contribution to disaster and resilience research in its focus on a Native American population, using baseline data on multiple dimensions of physical and psychological well-being, social capital, and modern forms of human capital.
